description.text:
Have Fun!

This is a fidget spinner where the finger pads are interlocking gears, and they turn when the spinner turns, but at a faster rate.

Makes a pretty nice gear sound, and is fun to play with

I have a .mov that I would like to share, but don't know how, so if anyone could comment how to do it, that would be great.

The gear bearing caps will work with any spinner that has the holes of the bearings 28mm apart.

Print 2 gears for each bearing, or one if you only want them on one side.

UPDATE: Added a compatible trispinner, currently printing so will post picture when finished.

Printer:

Da Vinci Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

Any

Notes:

I used a brim because my printer has terrible adhesion to the build plate, but it was really annoying to get the extra plastic out of the gears. If you don't have much warping usually, then no raft or brim is needed.

author: darkdecenet

description.text:
Reciprocating Drive Fidget.

Bill of Materials:
1 Handle (support touching build plate)
1 Piston Guide
2 Pinions (support touching build plate)
2 Pinion Caps
2 Pistons
2 Piston Caps
2 Gears

I recommend print the pinions before the gears, and measure across the pinion gear teeth. It is supposed to be 14mm, but it ends up being 13.8mm on my printer. There are four options for the gear with different pinion hole sizes. I'd choose the one that is 0.1mm larger than the actual pinion gear size.

After verifying the assembly, I used epoxy glue to make it permanent.

Printed in PLA.

https://youtu.be/WH8mvqOp9JE
https://youtu.be/_Pl7P0BUYfI
https://youtu.be/0-pnyy4sUTc

I think maybe I did something wrong. I printed everything with a skirt. After I cleaned the parts of it, I was already too tired.

remixed_from.author: rjhuber
remixed_from.title: Glass Bed Bracket for Tronxy P802E

title: Glass Bed Bracket for Anet A8

description.text:
This is a simple adjustable corner bracket for a glass plate. It fits the Anet A8. Version 3 is in most cases the best choice for you. You can choose if you want to have a hole for an m3 nut. This will make it more durable.

Installation:
You can slide the brackets in and out. To hold them in place i use a thumbscrew (these that normally goes under the h-frame). Under the H:Frame i use 3d printed thumbscrews with m3 nuts. But you have to cut your springs in half otherwise they will be too tight because of the thumbscrew and the bracket itself.

Update: 01.03.17
I uploaded a new version. This bracket is now stronger and easiert to install. You can just slide it in and out but you will need 4 m3 nuts to secure the brackets from underneath. Also it is now universal and should fit more than just the anet a8.

Update 03.03.17
I just made it even stronger and even more universal because mine came loose after a while and they bend the screws.

Update 04.03.17
I saw the remix from rjhuber. Adding m3 nuts was a great idea. But i also like the new version of the bracket more so i implementet this feature in the new version too but i will leave the old version uploaded too. Choose which one you like more. I removed version 1 because i think it was a failure. I just didn't do enough testing. Version two is already usable but i would download the newest model.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

comments.text:
Sorry for the strange question, but what's the purpose?
I personally use binder clips, which clamp the glass plate down.
Is this model replacing them, and if yes how does it work?
Thank you in advance :)
comments.author: Papiertuete

comments.text: Yes it is. The problem with binder clips is that they can interfere with the printhead if you print large pieces. These brackets also are easier to adjust to glass plates that are not as big as the heatbed because it secures it with screws.
comments.author: Papiertuete

comments.text:
Thanks :)
But how is this holding the plate down?
comments.author: Tobi97l

comments.text: It doesn't. It just stops it from moving around. Gravity does the rest.
comments.author: Papiertuete

comments.text: Oh I See :) So it's not necessary?
comments.author: Tobi97l

comments.text: Am I crazy or is the screw hole not high enough to clear the bed and hot bed. I printed v3 and the screws are too low and just push into the bed. Want to make sure I'm doing it right
comments.author: elliotboney

comments.text:
Just an Info for Anet A6 users:
It does not fit on an Anet A6 printer. The brackets hit the acrylic frame when the heat bed slides.
comments.author: marcel_goergens

comments.text: Can you post a picture? Maybe i can fix it. Sadly i don't have an Anet A6 so i can't test it myself.

print_settings.Notes:: Print must be stopped to insert LEDs.

description.text:
This is a remix of Syfy's Killjoys - Lucy from amazing Sci-Fi TV-Show Killjoys.
I added the space for the 3mm LEDs in the thrusters which means it wont be able to fly ;-). I also scaled it down to 75% and united the left and right peaces since it fits well on my printplate since it's under 20cm (~7.9") long. The LEDs and cables are inserting during the print (make a loop at the end of the cable so that you can pull it out with a pair of tweezers) which makes it more difficult to print, but it's worth it.
I mounted to the wall with a ball joint that I made with amedrano's library.
If you have any questions or requests feel free to ask them.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Original

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

100µm

Infill:

20% honeycomb

Notes:

Print must be stopped to insert LEDs. This can be done manually (f.e. in pronterface) or by inserting G-CODE at the right position. I used the following code (test it on a small model first if your not that it will work):
G1 E-0.00422 F1800.000 ; pressure discharge
G0 X0 Y190 ; move the extruder to the left backside
M300 ; pause and wait for button press on printer
G28 X Y ; recalibrate the x and y axis since the motors loose steps when paused too long
G1 E0.00422 F1800.000 ; pressure advance

author: maiknms

title: Fat Shark FPV Goggle Battery with ON/OFF Switch and Power Indicator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Back Story

In between flights as I am switching out packs on my model I unplug the barrel jack from the goggles so as not to waste the power while they are just resting on my forehead. I am sure many of you do the same. My problem comes when it is time to blindly plug it back in while it is on my face. I will grope around with my fingers, misidentify the headphone jack as my target and struggle in vain for an embarrassingly long time to force the battery connector into it. A case could be made that if I am this clumsy with my hands, perhaps I should not be piloting drones. You may have a point. I will ponder this later.

Functionality

I decided to make a battery pack that I could leave plugged in and simply switch off when I don't need to draw power from it. While I was at it, I added a power indicator LED. The LED works differently than you might expect but you are free to build it any way you like or just omit it altogether.

Build Details

In my build, when the pack is switched "ON" it glows brightly when the pack is at 8.2V and gets dimmer all the way down to going out at around 7V. At its brightest the LED only draws a negligible 1mA of current when turned on. The wiring diagram is attached but I basically added a Zener diode in series with the LED to create the dimming behavior described above. These are just soldered point-to-point. I arrived at the Vz value experimentally and found 5.6V to be a good fit. If you don't want to go to the trouble just put an appropriately sized current limiting resistor in place of the zener diode. There is enough room for all the wiring but it is a tight fit in order to keep the overall size of the unit down.

Four M3x14mm screws are used to fasten the front and back pieces from the back side. I made the front and back cover from PETG and the strain relief block out of TPU. TPU or TPE is recommended for this particular part. As you will see in the images, the inside of the strain relief block is meant to be cinched down upon the cables with a small zip tie that will stay concealed inside the case when the project is complete. For this reason, the part was designed with the expectation of a reasonably flexible material. The stuff I used has a Shore hardness of 95A and it worked very well but I would not go any higher.

Happy building and please post your makes!

Parts List:

  • 2S JST-XH cable
  • 18650 Li-ion Cells
  • Two Position Switch
  • Zener Diodes (optional)
  • 5mm Blue LED
  • M3x14mm Thread Button Head Hex Screws
  • Hatchbox Blue PETG Filament (used for cover)
  • SainSmart White Flexible TPU (used for the strain relief block)

You'll need a fitting end switch, I had a ZIPPY VMN around, so the mounting hole is for that model:
http://www.zippy.com.tw/sw/show_detail.aspx?ps_rfnbr=314
Feel free to drill matching holes for your type of sensor, or modify the design to fit your switch.

title: Wanhao i3 Duplicator v2.1 Glass Bed Brackets

description.text:
I liked the concept of the original, especially after trying so many others out there. Most of them don't fit my machine or glass bed. I saw others requesting a version for the Duplicator v2.1, so I threw something together. Using Signstek 3D Printer MK2 MK3 Heated Bed Tempered Borosilicate Glass Plate 213x200x3mm I got from Amazon. It seems to be what most others use.

I built this in Fusion 360, but went ahead and exported both the single bracket and all corner bracket designs in IGS and STP format. If other formats are needed, I can upload those as well on request (as long as it's supported by Fusion 360).

I'll update this post once I get a chance to print and take pics. Please excuse the orientation. It'll more than likely need to be adjusted. Haven't figured out why models always come out facing the wrong axis. -90º on the X should do it though.

Cheers!

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I print in ABS+, but PETG or other high temp filaments should be fine. Resolution shouldn't matter, or infill.

Edit: So after printing them and putting them on the bed, it seems like a good fit. It's pretty snug though, so depending on how exact your glass is, it may need a few tweaks.

The only thing I didn't take into account was that no part of this bracket clamps the glass to the bed. That was originally why I wanted this piece, but it may cause issue for glass tops that have warped. We'll see I guess.

comments.text: Printed these today. How exactly are they supposed to stay on the plate around the glass? I have the V2.1 with the same glass bed mentioned from Amazon. Thanks.
comments.author: Sbbrown333

comments.text: You'll still need the binder/bulldog clips to keep these on your bed plate.  They do allow for better positioning so your nozzle fan or other parts of the extruder assembly don't run into them.  I place mine on the long side of the brackets, and take off the top fin from the binder clip just to be safe. So far so good on my printer.  Hopefully you have similar luck.
comments.author: Sbbrown333

comments.text: FYI - the parts are coming out oriented wrong because by default Fusion360 does not put the z-axis pointing up like most other software. I have no idea why, but maybe it has to do with the intention that users start from a sketch which might make this orientation more natural (?). You can easily change it in the Fusion360 'Preferences' -> "Default modeling orientation".
comments.author: Flashpass

comments.text: Appreciate it. I actually just found that option this weekend. Haven't modeled anything new though, so havent had a chance to see if that fixed things. Cheers!

It is an improvement I made to Greg Wade’s Herringbone extruder idler. The springs holding the idler in place, always used to pop out from their place, forcing me to watch the prints permanently or to lose a lot of work when I wasn’t around to watch. So that I decided to do something to avoid this. The result is the one you see. To print it, you should use a support for the retracted part of the base or if you think it is too hard, print the idler without a support and after printing, use a flat or triangular file to bring it to the right shape. Either way, the idler springs will never pop out again!
I made the design using AutoCAD 2000 (dwg. file format)

You'll want to experiment a bit with this design in your slicer-of-choice before leaving this to print unattended.  Definitely use your slicer's gcode visualization function to assure you won't get completely hollow or "lacey" walls on the pieces.

description.text:
My daughter's really into art -- so much so that (without a bit of help) her desk could easily turn into a pile of art pens. So she was looking for a way to organize all her markers, and I cooked up this design in order to help.

My family artist prefers Prismacolor and Copic markers, so this little gizmo is sized to comfortably hold 36 of either -- obviously, it'd hold smaller pens and pencils as well. Print one top, one bottom, and four corners -- add a bit of super glue, and you've got an organizer!

26 Dec. 2017 Update:
Since Simplify 3D now behaves properly with thin walls, I revisited this design and uploaded 3 revised files (with "_thin" suffix) -- these have thin (0.8mm) walls between the cells, allowing for slightly larger cells for those... difficult... pens.

Notes:

Some slicers (I'm looking at you, S3D!) have real issues with printing thin vertical walls. You'll want to experiment a bit with this design in your slicer-of-choice before leaving this to print unattended. Definitely use your slicer's gcode visualization function to assure you won't get completely hollow or "lacey" walls on the pieces.

www.hppodcraft.com

If you have a 3D printer then print out part1 and part2 stl files and just slot them together. DONE. If you don't have a 3D printer you can still join in the fun! All you need is a normal printer, some cardboard and some imagination. Just follow the instructions:
  • 1. Print the hpllp-cutout pdf onto paper.
  • 2. Glue the paper onto some cardboard.
  • 3. Decorate it however you want.
  • 4. Cut along the lines. The radio waves are a bit tricky and you may need to use a knife. Be sure to get a grown-up to help you with this part.
  • 5. Slot the two parts together and enjoy!

This is from Kerbal Space Program. The Kerbal-X is a starter MK-1 Moon lander. The boosters will be made later on.

Kerbal Space Program for all computers Mac, Windows, and Linux!

https://kerbalspaceprogram.com/en/

The Catalina flying boat is a WW2 era maritime patrol plane. It was used as an anti-submarine plane amongst other things.

This is the old version of the Catalina. For the new, better version, go here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2401976

I didn't make this design from scratch. I downloaded the original model from here: https://www.cgtrader.com/free-3d-models/aircraft/other/catalina
Once I got the model, I used 3D Builder (Windows 10 default 3D designer) to split it down the middle. Exported it, then loaded it into Tinkercad (a simple, browser-based, editor). From there I removed the propellors, thickened the wing struts and tail, added that piece of the hull underneath the tail, retracted the undercarriage, added the gunning blisters and added floats on the end of the wings.

If you want a version with the floats or wheels down (or some other variation), leave a comment and I could design one (don't be shy), but I won't unless someone wants it.

comments.text:
Beautiful model, I have a metal version wing span 15 cm.
I'm flying the Dutch version PH-PBY and I'm going to print it
comments.author: 3Dfreakfreak

comments.text: I always liked the PBY.  If you are still inclined, my interest would be in:
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Hi, thanks for inquiring! I like the thought of turning into an RC plane, I think it would be great! However, I don't think that it would really fly, mainly because the aerofoil just seems too fat and unrealistic. As well as that, I can't do much editing with it because I didn't make the original model, so making the side of the tail smooth and things like that is a bit difficult and wouldn't give the greatest results. As well as that, I don't have any experience with printing flying planes, I'm mostly just into ornamental ones.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text:
I'm always interested. I have a Guillows Catalina that I know building would be fun but way way protracted. In printed form I would (if I had the skills):
1) Add carbon fiber tube spars
2) Hollow out as much as I can
3) Separate out the elevator, rudder and ailerons
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text:
Well, ok, I'll give it a shot then. I hope it works. Before I start designing, I just need a few more details:
-How big did you have in mind?
-How big are the motors (If you have lots of different sizes, how big should the space inside the cowling be)?
-How will the motors be mounted?
-How you were planning to hold on the ailerons, elevator and rudder (hinges, yogurt container, etc...)?
-What's the thickness of the carbon fibre spars?
-Do you want the wheels up, down, folding (I can't really do folding ones very well) or non-existent (like PBY-5 and older versions)?
-Should the floats be up or down?
-Are you planning to use it in water (I wouldn't if I was you)?
-Which type of nose would you like?
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Also, I just started work on a new, fresh, built from scratch Catalina, which will be much better than this one, so that'll be the one which I'll try to modify for remote control.
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text: Well that's pretty darn awesome.  To answer your questions:
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text: Do the wings from (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:86982) have ailerons? If it doesn't, I'd suggest one that does. I just noticed that there's no visible ailerons on the photo. I'll still use it, but I just thought it might make it a bit challenging to fly.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Those wings do not have ailerons. However, I have printed them and it should be structurally easy enough to add them outboard. You would just establish the outboard wing section with the ailerons cut out from the trailing edge of the wing. You could go with a simple triangular cross section, or get all fancy and give the aileron a curved leading edge. That would make it a differential aileron: http://www.aerospaceweb.org/question/dynamics/q0045.shtml
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text: Great! I'll get onto it soon! After I finish the fuselage. Oh, and I think I should use the tail from the plane too, because, again, hollowing it out would be hard and they may not be very good aerodynamically. I could probably modify the tail to look more like the Catalina's, to preserve the look. What do you think? It would be much easier and probably quicker.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Sorry, forgot to answer your first question: yes the tail on that plane is super solid.  I printed this whole thing and it came out really well.  Back then it was on a Solidoodle (long since retired).  The elevators tended to be fragile, but treatment with the XTC 3D resin makes all the difference.
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text: I have owned several.  I had a Grumman AA-1A which I flew all over for 10 years.  Then I had a Piper Apache (ugh, that one was a lemon).  After that I had a TB-10.  These days I putter around in a C172, a Piper Seminole and a Piper Arrow.  I am building a Zenith 650HDS and a Personal Cruiser (Corvair Cruiser) in the garage....as if I don't have enough projects.
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text: Cool! I like the look of the Zenith. Nice.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Just awesome.  I don't think you need a locking mechanism.  Positive control by the servo would take care of that.  The static model looks GREAT!  For suspension, I can look to see how 3DLabPrint implemented their C172 nose gear implementation, which does simulate an oleo strut.  Pen springs would work, ostensibly so long as you specify a diameter for said spring.
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text:
Actually, on second thoughts, it might be better to use some sort of rc car shocks or Lego shocks (http://www.brickowl.com/catalog/lego-large-shock-absorber-with-hard-spring-2909#buy) for the suspension. I think about 3 inch long shocks would be adequate for this model.
Also, do all the landing gear mechanisms need to use the same servo, or can they be all separate? And what about landing gear doors?
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: For an R/C bird or even a static display bird that looks great.  I like what you have there.  For the shocks you might also look at the Open RC Truggy and the rest of the Open RC line.  I think we can use the Lego shocks but we'd need to scale the airplane accordingly.  Generally one servo runs all the landing gear, usually via a system of control rods or some such.  However, I can imagine the main gear being run with one servo and a work gear to raise and lower them.  The other thing is that we can leave them down and locked all the time so long as we make them sturdy.  This airplane is draggy anyway and those wheels hanging in the breeze won't add a whole lot more.  For a scale model the doors would be essential.  For an RC model, I think you can leave off the nose wheel doors.
comments.author: TurboRenegade

comments.text: Well, I think retracts are still a good idea. Having them always down won't look right, and having them up would make the landings pretty bad (the hull will go green). I don't think they'd be too hard to design. I uploaded a very bad diagram of a retractable design to this model's photos. Instead of using a shock, it just uses a shock's spring (something like this [https://hobbyking.com/en_us/desert-fox-front-shocks-spring-2pcs.html] although not necessarily those particular springs). There's a piece of string to pull the wheels up without stretching the spring. Also, not included in the diagram, there would be a cog connected to the hinge with the red arrow, and, because there'd be one on each side of the plane, the cogs would connect and then could use one servo for both of them. I would design it so that the servo connects to one of the cogs in a way similar to that of a steam train's piston connecting with the wheels.
comments.author: SkyRider

description.text:
Took the immortal model (from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067778) and added the joints.

Still printing to see if everything sorta fits together.

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

14 or 23

Notes:

You may need to sand and/or make holes bigger or play with the size of the pegs.

Instructions

Print:

  • 4 Legs
  • 3 Pegs
  • 1 Pelvis
  • 1 Head
  • 1 Right Arm
  • 1 Left Arm

I printed mine with rafts and supports but you can play with the settings depending on the part and your printer.

Ensamble:

Clean all holes and pegs and balls and sockets.
Carefully insert each leg onto the pelvis.
Attach the head to the pelvis using a peg.
Attach left and right arms using a peg.

title: Wanhao i3 Maker Select Filament Guide & Riser - 4mm Short

description.text:
I really loved the original design, but because I had a spool holder that was more or less frankensteined, I needed a shortened screw bracket and extended arm for clearance. I've tossed in the source files in case anyone wants to make changes.

Cheers!

Already have inquiries on the spool holder. So, here are the two things I used to create it.

Prusa i3 mk2 Easy Spool Holder/Rollers - Low Rider Remix
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1967113
I printed the nuts and bolts (2 each) w/ PLA, and the rollers (2) out of TPU

Wanhao i3 Duplicator Spool Holder
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1635585
I printed the left, right, and locks (2) out of PLA. I had to drill/file out the M5 holes on left, right, and locks to fit the M8 bolts I printed. May be easier to just edit the obj file. I also edited the locks to slim things down to 2mm depth, but I doubt that'll be an issue.

Toss the bearings inside the rollers (4 total), put the locks upside down between the left/right and rollers. Additionally, if you do edit the left/right files for the holes, you can add a vertical piece (I'd use the lock as a template) so that if the spool tracks left or right, it has something to stop it. I already had it printed, so I just flipped the lock pieces.

Cheers!

Monoprice Maker Select v2

description.text: My RC aircraft handle on the ground better it they have a little wheel toe-in. For those planes that have the bent aluminum landing gear use a pair of these wedges on each wheel to add about 4° of toe-in. One wedge is placed on the outside (wheel side) of the aluminum pointing forward and a second wedge on the inside with thin edge pointing back. See the picture of the wedges on my Pulse 15e shown from underneath. The nose of the plane is to the left and if you look closely you can see the wheel slightly toed in toward the fuselage. This was designed for a landing gear with an 18mm wide aluminum strut and axle hole centered. The wedge could be scaled up or down for different width struts. This thing was made with Tinkercad. A camera slider. Comes in several parts. The camera mounting plate has holes for 1/4" and 3/8". The rods are meant to be 19.3 mm in outer diameter, I used metal railing supports. The rollers are meant to have bearings set in the middle during the print. The bearings are just normal skateboard bearings. The rollers are meant to be attached to the mounting plate with machine screws and nuts. Roller V2 is has a larger hole to accommodate nuts

Supports:
The mounting plate prints well if positioned with the mounting surface flat on the build plate, and supports touching build plate for the hardware insets. The other pieces do not require supports (at your discretion, of course).

Infill:
The rollers should have reasonably high infill; around 50-60% is fine. The mounting plate and end caps can have much less. 5-10% is fine for those.

title: Mounting Plate for 2 in 1 out Switch Hotend for Geeetech Prusa I3

description.text:
Update 12/6/17 I AM PLANNING ON CHANGING THE COOLING SCHEME FROM AN AXIAL FAN TO A RADIAL FAN. I ADDED THE FIRST CUT AT THE DUCT AND A TEMPORARY TRANSITION PIECE USING A 30 MM AXIAL FAN . THE DUCT MOUNTS ON THE BACK, NEAREST THE LINEAR BEARINGS, SO IT DOESN'T INTERFERE WITH THE LAYER FAN AND MAKES IT EASY TO CHANGE HOT-ENDS. I HAVEN'T TRIED IT YET, AND IT MAY BE IN-PROCESS FOR SEVERAL MONTHS. PLS LET ME KNOW IF YOU TRY THIS AND HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS.

Update 4/16/17 Added link to information on using a Y-block hotend. 4/19 https://1drv.ms/w/s!AoMNMLsOFAgFj-AnywOk94qGBizVrg
Update 3/30 Changed spacer and plate with closed bottom to 3 hole version.
Update 3/15 I found that this hotend requires a higher filament temp than the one I had been using. Also, the extruder PIDs needed adjustment to keep the temperature more constant than the larger one I had been using. I used to get good results with one PLA type at 193 deg. Now I believe something over 200 is required for the same filament. The following PIDs seem to work well at a print temp of 202 C: Kp 13.5 Ki 0.8 Kd 57.6. The heater block is uninsulated at this time. I've found it's worthwhile to add some insulation to the block. I use cereal box paper secured with kapton tape.

Update 3/13/17 Added a couple photos of the part installed in a very thin test print of the bracket. The part looks very good. So far, I've only used it as a single extruder. The heat break is very effective. The upper part of the block stays very cool when printing PLA, even without the fan running. There are holes on the back of the upper block for a layer cooling fan. I've removed my cooling fan temporarily from the extruder bracket while I'm testing things. More updates as I figure out the scripts required to make it function as a switcher.

Update 2/27 minor tweak in cavity dimensions. Added 2 mm Spacer.
updated 3/17 I only printed this part as a lite-weight test-prototype. It is for mounting a new 2-to-1 hot end that is similar to a Cyclops, but permits two filaments to be switched between one output. It will not mix two filament streams and does not have the backflow problem if you only load one filament in the block. ==============================================================

The plate is intended to mount on a single extruder mounting plate like that furnished with the Geeetech I3 Pro B printer with 50 mm mounting centers. When this design is proven, I expect to be able to switch between the Cyclops/Chimera clone setup I have on this printer and this 2 to 1 switch hotend with minimal readjustment of the printer. That means I will adjust the bracket as necessary to get close to the same vertical height as I currently have on my Cyclops clone using the mounting plate and spacer I designed. I expect the plate will mount on top surface of the extruder bracket with the hotend mounting holes below the mounting plate.
I recently received the part, but have done little testing. I found it on AliExpress. I also found it on eBay when I was researching a new extruder today. You can probably find it as I did by searching for: HOTEND 2 IN 1 OUT.

A first look at the part shows that it runs much cooler than expected in the area of the mounting holes, so PLA will probably be what I'll use for the final bracket. The part mounts through the rectangular hole in the plate, but the .STL file has a thin surface covering this hole. The purpose of the surface is to keep the plate bonded to the bed during printing if you use ABS; being only 0.6 mm thick, it can be easily cut out when finished. I also added a version with the hole open.

I have high hopes for this part for use as an easy way to switch between filaments during a print. My Cyclops setup is OK as a mixer but tricky when trying to use it as a switcher with high ratios between the two filaments. The printer manager will require some code to retract the unused filament back into the cool zone and advance the other filament when the extruder is switched.

Printer:

Prusa I3 Modified

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 is OK

Infill:

25% Hex should be plenty

Notes:

I will probably use 4 perimeters and 3 top/bottom layers. A brim will help keep the part on the bed if printed in ABS.

Cut out the thin bottom on the rectangular hole. I think the holes are sized for using nuts, but they may have to be opened slightly. I prefer to cut threads into the part for mountng, but the location of the part may make it difficult to cut threads into the plate, so that also is an uncertainty.
Sketchup 2017

description.text:
These are replacement cases for a usb drives (a/k/a jump drives, thumb sticks, or flash drives). These designs are meant to encase the naked circuit board with the usb port sticking out. Two sets of files are provided. One for an older Cruze stick and another for a generic drive.

title: Mobius/Runcam Pan Tilt with 9 Gram Servos

description.text:
I present my very own Pan Tilt module designed around cheap 9 gram metal gear servos for the Mobius and RunCam HD/ HD 2 action cameras. I tried many of the pan tilts here on thingiverse and always had some things that I didn't like about the design so decided to make my own.

The design is super simple and very robust. I'll post some flying video the next chance i get to take it up.

Print settings I used.
PLA
.2 mm Layer Height
30% infill - honeycomb
No Supports needed

I tried to keep tolerances loose but not too loose. I had to take a file to a few of the holes to get them to fit.

Servos I'm using...
TGY-R5180MG - 180 degree pan servo. I used the wheel arm for added structural support.

TGY-50090M - Tilt servo.

I use velcro to hold the camera to the top plate and so far it seems more than adequate.

I have also included the inventor files in case you want to use different servos and need to move holes/ spacing around.

Would love to have suggestions to make it better.

Flight Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oBQkNS8b8bs

Thanks.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

If you happen to own one of those "Smart Panel" shower walls from Smart Showers (or another similar re-seller of china's poor designs) you may find that the flow destination selector switch is getting stuck. This kind of shower comes in different styles, but uses the same valves. You probably have one of those showers if you have at least a waterfall, hand shower and jets. Another tell-tale sign of this kind of shower is that the water temperature/flow selector is on the bottom with a feature selector right above it. What happens is that who ever makes them in China has used very crappy plastic and it is sure to fail within a few years (mine failed after about 3 years). I've ended up taking two different versions of the shower apart (for me and my parents), and had to redesign the failed part on the shower with 3 way selector. A bigger version for a 4 way selector is available too, just search for it.

Feel free to chat in case you have questions about how to take the shower apart, be careful about using too much force though, quality of the materials they've used is a complete garbage.

Hope this part will help, seems like a common problem to me which can be repaired in a couple of hours.

title: Cat Food Dispenser - Triple Auger Feeder

description.text:
I have three cats and was trying to figure out a neat way to feed them all equal amounts and at the same time elegantly. I obtained the original concept from kitlaan and ultimately settled on using a stepper driven single auger with 2" PVC set up for three independent flow paths.

I began with the Noodlepie1002 auger and removed the ends and a 1/2" core from the model. This was printed enough times to get the overall desired length. These were epoxied onto a 1/2" aluminum tube. In addition, the prints were coated in epoxy, sanded, and coated again to reduce friction and strengthen.

Next, I assembled the PVC "T"s in such a way to deliver the food through three flow paths. The 2" PVC tubes that interconnect the T's were chamfered on a lathe to minimize any internal abrupt surfaces. (I'm sure this could also be done with a little bit of elbow grease.)

The motor block was made to take any combination of NEMA17 or 23, with or without a planetary gearbox. I decided to go with a 1:5 NEMA17. Be careful not to use too high of a gear ratio. Some higher ratios like 1:100 can only deliver about 4Nm of torque before you risk damaging the gearbox. You would rather skip steps than shred gear teeth.

The motor block has a small notch built into it. This lets you push-and-twist the block into place. If the twist to lock direction is opposite the auger feed direction, it will have a tendency to secure the motor block and prevent it from falling off over time.

I've built a small wood enclosure/hopper for the feeder. This is aesthetic mostly and let's the whole thing pass the wife's inspection. It's 1/2" oak plywood with some trim and plexy sight glass. I don't have any plans for the enclosure. I mostly like to wing this sort of thing and with a healthy application of trim you can hide almost anything.

Included are some pictures of my wiring diagram and a picture of the final prototyping board. I ran all the interconnects below the board to keep things neat and this is mounted inside the box near the motor. My code is included and has plenty of notes. I'm not a very good coder and need to comment EVERYTHING or else I forget after a month or two and edits need to be made. Similar to kitlaan's code, this moves the auger in the forward direction to deliver food, then back to un-jam, and repeats. However, unlike kitlaan, I use a stepper rather than a servo.

I just finished the code and am about to test it out on the cats for the first time. I'll keep this updated with any changes. Feel free to ask any questions!

Here are some of the parts I used:
1/2" Aluminum Tubing - https://www.mcmaster.com/#9056k65/=16im13o
1/2" ID Bearing - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00VNVFY42/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Stepper Driver - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/12859
Arduino - https://www.adafruit.com/products/2000
Shaft Coupler - http://www.ebay.com/itm/171991954669
Stepper motor/Gearbox - http://www.ebay.com/itm/322128759561?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Printed "pointing up".
Epoxy coating for smooth texture and strength.

Thanks to @TES737 for the design starting point and to @chrisqwerty for the Titan dummy design for reference:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1514324

This modified design of a Titan mount puts the center of the top of the hot end in exactly the same position as it does with the default extruder that comes with the 8" Pegasus.

I have an 8" Makerfarm Pegasus with lead screw upgrades and I'm not willing to give up print area. Designs that put the motor on the right run into the problem that the hot end is fairly far forward and so some Y print area is lost. Another issue is that the Titan is fairly compact and so the hot end is higher, and hence the Z axis is lower at the home position to the point that the X axis extrusions run into the couplers on the Z motors. Other Thingiverse designs have issues with the mount running into the ends of the X axis.
This mount design should place the center of the top of the hot end in the same place as the extruder that comes with the 8" Makerfarm -- and so no print area is lost and the X axis doesn't run into the motor couplers. The motor needs to be on the left.

description.text:
This is a dual end point (two PEX pixel arches meet at this point) yard mount for RGB PEX pixel arches for Holiday Decorators. This mount is held to the ground with two tent stakes (spikes) and a tie wrap is tied around the top portion of the mount to the PEX to keep it in place. A single mount is also listed here for the end points of the run of arches. These were built from standard PLA with 20 - 25% infill and held up nicely through out the winter. The only one that got broken was from the snow thrown on it during the extremely heavy year of snow - (worst in almost 50 years). Fast and easy to set up. The slot in the side is for the wire to slide through at the end of the arch. Very happy how these turned out.

*NOTE** A flaw was pointed out in the original file. I have uploaded a revision..

title: Anet A8 Dovetail Accessory and Spoolholder Mount

description.text:
Dovetail mount spool holder with ability to mount future accessories such as a filament guide, light or camera, perhaps even a bowden extruder. The holder mounts between the printer frame and the LCD board (after removing original spacers).
Spool holder tower spacing is adjustable, so either original threaded rod or a customized rod can be used. The rod openings are closed on the outsides so that there is no need for nuts or other devices to keep the rod positioned horizontally. The end walls can be cut or broken out if a longer rod is used.
The adjustable position plus closed-end rod holders allows for the use of wide spools or large spool adapters.
Dovetail test pieces are provided to test whether the dovetails will work with your printer settings before you commit to printing the large pieces.

This design was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1505075 by DeAtHfOrToLd and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1743397 by dldesign (remix of DeAtHfOrtoLd's) but I didn't call it a remix since it doesn't actually use anything directly from either of those designs. I actually printed the one from dldesign, but found that some wide spools don't fit between the posts, and neither did my current favorite spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1241566) so I decided a wider one was needed.
BTW, another option I didn't see until after I made mine is this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064776 by tzahov. It uses a very cool mounting technique.

UPDATE: I added a couple of simple filament guides. One is 50mm long, the other is 70mm.

NOTE: DO NOT try to print the "assembled" STL. It is not likely to work well, that file is included only for the purpose of showing what the full assembly looks like.

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

All dovetails should be printed facing up, and in the same X/Y orientation. If you print one side horizontally on the print bed and the other vertically, the resulting fit may be affected by variations in scaling between the two axes.

Supports are needed only for the openings on the top ends of the towers (called "arms" in files)

The dovetail fit is likely to be a bit finicky. Please print the test pieces first to make sure the dovetails fit together before wasting a bunch of plastic and time on the larger pieces. If you can't find slicer settings that give working dovetails, let me know and I will try to help you. If needed I could make a second set of parts with looser fitting dovetails.

I originally used a single dovetail, but the spool holder towers were too wobbly. Using two dovetails fixed this problem. I also added some holes to attach clamping pieces to the back, but these were not needed so I didn't need to design those pieces.
The grooves across the backs of the parts are there to reduce the possibility of warping. The first tower I printed warped badly enough to be completely unusable. Grooves on the front of the towers are there for cosmetics only, they match the grooves on the back.

comments.text:
I printed this out in very high resolution (took 16 hours). Its a great idea so here is my critique which follows exactly what you already know.
1) Dovetails are not tight enough. Way too loose to depend on a heavy filament reel not falling off. Using a screw would just pull it off the rail. I am thinking if you went tight enough to require a little silicon lubricant to move freely, that would be better.
2) I do the same thing with my initials on my work, but quickly noticed the downside. No support for the inside of the B makes it look bad. For a picky person, yet someone very appreciative of your efforts, I would vote to remove the initials.It is also VERY difficult to remove excess plastic on the bed side.
3) The scoring lines you made between the holes... since you need to print with supports, it fills them up, then you need to use a knife to remove them, also making the work look shoddy. Its not your fault, its the guy trying to route out the grooves with a knife, then sanding. I would remove the grooves if it were me.
comments.author: DeveK

comments.text: Oh yeah, forgot to mention...this may seem like a bit too much of a hack, but you might be able to use your print with loose dovetails by drilling the hole all the way through and using a bolt with nut to pull it together instead of pushing it apart...not a perfect solution, but I hate to see a 16 hour print wasted.
comments.author: DeveK

comments.text: Hi DeveK,
comments.author: DeveK

comments.text:
Its a great design. I am very particular about quality, so here are a few steps I take to make sure it comes out pristine...
1) I use a piece of 220x220x3mm tempered glass then sandblasted lightly to make a rougher yet nice surface. Works great. Never wears and cleaning is just rubbing some alcohol or lacquer thinner over the surface after printing.
2) The nozzle is .4 so I use .38 in the settings. That way everything is tight and there is no look of threading at the end. The actual overall dimensions of the part are not changed in doing this. I also print with .1 quality and usually do at least 50% infill. Takes forever, but I am always impressed with the part. I find that bed heating using PLA with the glass is 75 initial, 65 after that.

title: Anet A8 SFX Corsair SF450 Power Supply Mount

description.text: This is a psu mount for the Anet A8 and Corsair SF450 power supply. It would probably work for other SFX power supplies, but I am not positive on that. I printed this at 100% infill since the power supply simply clips into the bracket. You will need to drill your own mounting holes. Simply hold the bracket up to the frame where the stock power supply goes and use the existing holes in the frame as a template. Use flat head screws and countersink the holes. This is my first ever project designed in cad, but I am quite happy with how it turned out. Just fyi, this mount took 9 hours to print at 100% infill.

description.text:
This is part spinner, part wheel. It uses a 3" O-ring as a tire and is a good spinner, but is also fun to roll across the floor or desktop. Leaning at an angle will make it roll in a circle back to you. And the spiral is flexible enough to act like a spring, so it even bounces. Uses 608 bearing without seals and lube.

Update 3-5-17- Added a 3-arm version of the 3" wheel. Added 3 and 4-arm version of 4" wheel, added a solid center wheel that takes a size 223 o-ring (1 7/8" O.D., 1 5/8" I.D., 1/8" diameter). Also made a pusher that you can use as an alternate means of launching.

Included are pics of part numbers and dimensions for 3 and 4 inch o-rings I got at Ace hardware, if I were doing a bunch of these I would find a source to buy them cheaper in bulk online. I found some 3" o-rings at Amazon - https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0051XZ6KU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

2 spiral wheels can be combined to make a good optical illusion similar to some other designs I've seen out there, but with bearings for better spinning. I use the small dowels shown in the picture to connect the 2 wheels, available at Ace Hardware, or probably any hardware store.
Videos of the launcher and optical illusion
https://youtu.be/_Di3f4jw_Aw
https://youtu.be/R-DSSmePoXE

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

.3

Notes:

Use a 3" o-ring for the tire. Did at .3 resolution, 5 perimeters, 3 top 3 bottom layers, no infill, the perimeters make it solid. Transparent Red WYZ PLA at 215 head, 35 bed. Print time 37m:38s. For the 223 version, recomend 100% fill for weight if you want longer spin times.
For the wheel pusher 2.2 5p 3t3b .2inf . The pusher has a hole in the handle to plug in a 3/8 dowel rod if you want to give it extra length. i just checked it, a little tight, running a drill bit through it to clean the seams should make it fit.

The cap in my hand is the one included, I had put other ones in there before I made those. They are better because you get some grip from the grooves. Groovy. Settings for cap are .3 res, 5 perimeters, 3 top 3 bottom and 50% infill. Beware, I have found if I print the caps at .2 resolution they are too tight.

I notice I see noise on the preview pics where the spiral arms join the rim and center, they really are solidly attached, I'm sure this is from the boole I used on them. I tried running one through NetFabb, but the fixed file looks the same. Ignore it, they print fine.

title: Temp Controlled Build Enclosure for UM2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Parts

1200 X 600 X 3mm Sheet (PVC, Acrylic etc.)
12V 40mm Fan
12V Power Supply
Chassis socket (to suit 12V Power Supply plug)
temperature controller on ebay http://www.ebay.com/itm/9-C-99-C-DC-12V-Intelligent-Digital-Led-Thermostat-Temperature-Controller-/321723841989
Clear Drying Glue
5 metres 6mm X 9mm white door seal strip
Clear Packaging tape
Masking Tape or similar
4 - 20mm X 4mm Screws
67 - 10mm X 3mm Screws
9 - 16mm X 3mm Screws
3 - 25mm X 3mm Screws
9 – 3mm nylock nuts
3mm washers
2 magnets to hold door one needs to be thin.

Instructions

Download Pictures for Instructions zip file and STLs zip file from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2137342/#files
I printed all parts in ABS with 2mm walls and thicker for hinges
Cut out panels from sheet to nearest mm
Print joiners, all front door parts, door frame mounts and joiner first
Mount front door hinges by replacing current UM screw with a 16mm screw on each one
Use a 16mm Screw for the front door handle.
Glue a thin magnet to the back of the door handle and tape a magnet behind the UM front panel.
Use masking tape to hold panels together making sure that the top panel sits between the left and right panel and not on top of them
Mark holes and drill panels making sure Joiner L4 is positioned in the gap of the cable ducts
Mount joiners and door frame mounts with 10mm screws on panels
Use clear packaging tape to join and seal panels where desired
Glue Top Door frame to joiners right way up and don’t use screws
Put Door seal on the Top door frame
Tape top door in place with masking tape and use the Top Hinges Template to mark mounting holes for the hinges.
Use 6 X 16mm screws for the Top Body Hinges
Mount Left handle with 3 X 25mm screws and Nyloc Nuts
Thread thermocouple through the Thermocouple holder and attach it to the 25mm Left handle mounting bolts with nyloc nuts.
Push thermocouple far enough onto its holder so that the print head will miss it in the fully left position
Mount right handle with 10mm screws and nyloc nuts
Mount the 40mm fan to the fan shroud using 4mm screws
If printing in ABS use enclosure as is to print tall parts like the Bowden grommets
Ground wire goes from the Power Socket to the -DC terminal on the Temperature Controller and the Black wire on the fan.
12V positive from power socket goes to the +DC terminal on the Temperature Controller and to one side of the relay contacts.
The other side of the relay contacts goes to the red wire of the fan.
Glue the cable ducts in place
Duct Lid slides in position from underneath
Un-attach the Bowden cable(s)
Mount the Right Bowden grommets flush with the outside panel of the UM then the left flush with the outside of the UM and with the print head cables passing through the slot.
Join the grommets together with the 2 X 10mm screws there will probably be a gap between them
Set start temp at the desired temperature and stop temperature to 1 degree above that. (Picture shows set at 45 degrees with current temp at 25 degrees.

description.text:
If you print this thing and find it useful, please consider hitting that "Tip Designer"
button and help support more designs.

I have suspension forks on my bike which does not have eyelets for full length mudguards. Clip-ons and half size mountain bike mudguards just were not going to cut it as this is for my commuter bike.

The diameter of the forks is 38mm so the curve of the mount follows this. Most forks are probably fairly similar.

There are 2 different designs with the curve depending where you need this bracket to sit with the nut trap on each side of the designs, just pick the one you want.This bracket is designed to be mounted with two cable ties and foam backed double sided tape (3m VHB will do). Nut traps are tight, heat gently or just scale up the print 1-2%.

Hardware (screws and washer should all be about m3, locknuts and sprung washers are a given where this is going to take a little abuse. Just make sure you have spare cable
cable ties if something breaks.

Its a pretty small design, will also fit between the post mounts on my forks and around the caliper, just bend your mudguard stays with a good pair of pliers to reach around. Your mileage may vary.

print_settings.Notes:: If you orient them correctly, no supports are needed.

description.text:
Update: Made a new integrated fan and mount for the radial fan. This design is modified for a different set up (30x30mm fan) I am currently designing but since I never liked the original design I figured I'd share tjhis now in the interim. The way the radial fan mounts is you'll have to drill/tap for a m3 bolt to fit in the hole. You'll then want to grab a m3x25mm bolt, put a washer on it, then through the fan mounting hole, then another washer and a split washer. The split washer isn't necessary but I like the tension it adds. This design is meant to to swivel and snap into place. It will make more sense when the new assembly is made/released as to why the swivel is there. To mount the assembly, you'll squish it between the 40x40 fan and the sideFanv2 file. You'll want to use all 4 screws to mount it. It allows for z axis adjustment this way. I have the bottom of this mount about 20mm below the bottom face of the 40x40 mm. This should roughly direct the airflow to the tip of the nozzle.

Made upgrades to the original Reach 3D Printer or what I think are. Changed the mounting for the proximity sensor because I prefer using the nuts to make small adjustments. The nuts are a little hard to turn so I made a knurled nut holder to make adjustments easier. Changed the mount for the 40x40mm fan to blow only to the heat sink with two side rails to direct the perpendicular flow. Also added a circular fan for the hot end. The attachement snaps onto a 50mmx15mm blower fan. You'll need to print the fanSupport to mount it.You'll notice in the picture there is a nickel wedged between the fanSupport and the sideFan. The nickel pushes the fan support out of the way allow full bed print use. WIthout it, the fan support tends to bump into the Z-axis nut. A #4 wood screw is used to hold the circleFan to the fanSupport to allow vertical adjustments.

Concern: After a couple hours worth of prints I noticed the circleFan drooped 2mm at the worst place. This happened because the fan heats up due to how close it is but only droops because my heater wires are resting on the circleFan and pushing it down causing it to warp. I fixed the warp by heating my bed to 80 C and lettting the circleFan sit on it until it became flat again. There is a V2_1 (recommended) which is a basically a half circle. This provides adequate airflow and does not have a sag problem.

8.5mm motor version similar to the Tiny Whoop. I needed a bigger version of the TW for safely flying in the house, and this is what I designed. This build uses:

Scisky flight controller
CL 820-17 Dark Edition motors
Q25 16ch. VTX and camera
Ladybird 55mm props
Turnigy Graphene 65c 750mah battery

All up weight (without battery) is 51.4gr.

The motor caps protect the wires on the bottom of the motors and keep the motors from pushing up if you land hard. The caps are the right length to have the top of the motors flush with the top of the motor mounts in the frames.

With the 750Mah batteries I get 5.5 minutes of flying and 4.5 minutes of hard flying with no power dropoff. I land at 4.5 minutes and have 3.7v on the battery. You'll notice no components stick out above or below the frames, so the electronics are well protected.

This is a very easy print needing no rafts or supports. Enjoy and let me know how it works for you.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with the top/bottom flat on the bed.

description.text:
This Design lets you print simple boxes with lid in the dimensions you like.

You need Fusion360 for changing the dimensions.
Out of the box the model is 40x60xx35mm (on the inside).

Open the design in Fusion 360 and choose "modify" -> "change parameters".
Under "user parameters" you will find all the parameters that define the dimensions of the box. The parameters are commented.

I highly suggest printing a small sample first to test the friction fit of the lid.

Exporting all at once is kind of hidden:
Right-click on the first item in the "Browser" and choose "save as stl".

Printer:

XMachines Lorei

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200µ

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print with the top/bottom flat on the bed.

There are a only few things to consider when changing those values. Wall thickness should match the overall size of the box or the result will be very "flexible". The lip that holds the lid should not be taller than the inner height of the lid....but that's about all.

title: Dozenal D12 v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Version 2 of a 12 sided die with numbers in dozenal (base 12) I love role playing games and dozenal so this seemed like a natural fit! I'm somewhat surprised no one else had done this yet. The first version I made had ugly distinguishing marks for the 6 and 9, so I changed it to a subscript asterisk or "dit", what I use as the radix (decimal) point. I also changed the font and deepness of the numbers. Most crucially, this version has all opposing faces adding to 13 (11 in dozenal) The symbols used are:

dek (10): \u03C7 (χ)
el (11): \u0404 (Є)
radix: \u0359 ( ͙ )

More information on dozenal can be found on the Dozenal Society of America's website, I highly recommend it: http://www.dozenal.org/

description.text:
A rotating target stand designed for use with Nerf weapons. Designed to give me something to shoot at in the office without constantly needing to go over and stand the regular targets back up.

Each files are arranged to fit on a 200x200x150mm print area, though can be scaled for smaller areas with minimal issue.

Printer:

Prusa I3 Hesine

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10% for most, 20% for arms

Notes:

The base, targets and collar can all be printed at 10% infill. The arms may need greater infill if you find them too flexible once printed (I used 15% for mine).

Assembly

Test the collar sits on the stand and spins freely before assembling anything. Depending on your printer accuracy you may find its too tight and does not spin. In this case scale it up slightly and re-print. Once you have a collar that fits, follow the steps below for assembly.

Glue the arms into the targets using the small slot on one side. Once the glue has dried you can then glue the other end of the arm into the collar, again using the small slots as a guide.

Once the glue has hardened simply slot the collar over the top of the stand, when a target is hit it should force the collar to rotate and present another target.

author: bubbabutch

description.text:
This is a remix of the Aluminum 20XX extrusion V-slot mount. This has space for 2 titan extruders, for systems like the Chimera, Cyclops, or possibly the Kraken. (Not to mention countless other dual extruders.)

Edit: I was printing this out myself and realized that somehow some holes were introduced as artifacts in the STL file. I have gone back in and filled those holes and have uploaded the new, "holeless" file.

NOW LIVE ON KICKSTARTER https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1346069182/plexibots?ref=nav_search Extrusion
This is out extrusion profile. It is 20mm x 20mm cross section. The slots and the hole are designed to work with M4 screws.
Some interesting features --
The cross section of the slot is square. It can be used directly with standard M4 screws eliminating the need for specialty nuts. (ref OpenBeam)
Also the edge of the slot is chamfered to serve as a guide for wheels and balls which can be used to make a sliding mechanism. (ref V-Slot)
We have three push fit connection systems which can be used to connect extrusions in different configurations, no screws needed.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213821
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213819
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213819
Alternately we also have a set of joining plates and angles for stronger connections.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213776
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213750
We also provide parts to make a hinge or pivot joint.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213770
To make pivot joints that are powered (by a servo for example), please see our motor arms.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213764
To mount motors to our extrusion see our actuator adapters.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213762
To build a sliding mechanism see our slides.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213861
NOTES:
We are planning to get many of these parts molded so "makers" can buy em cheap and use for their projects. We need your feedback --
  • What other parts would you like added to the library?
  • What colors should different parts be molded in?
  • What would you build with it?
  • Would you like any parts modified?
    We welcome other comments and suggestions

description.text:
Universal spool holder for Prusa i3, also may fit other models.

Main advantage: spool is placed on moving rollers, which can be easily adjusted to any spool width - spool with any diameter and width can be placed, time for adjustment is couple of seconds.

Parts needed:

  1. 2 8mm rods
  2. Many 608 bearings (depends on how many rollers you want to install).

You will need to print two main supports, that should be screwed to printer frame. My printer (HicTop) had wires on the left side, so i've added two versions of main support, a normal one, and with cut-off for wires.

slider_end are not moving "sliders" to be put on the ends of the rod, like stoppers. You can make as many sliders as you want, depending on the lenght of rods you have. My version has 4 sliders, and 2 "end sliders", which allows me to put up to 3 spool at time.

P.S. I've inclded SolidWorks sources, for all version, but normally you should use the latest version of parts

P.S.S The wheel for bearings is not mine, i've found it somewhere on thingiverse. Also the idea of printed linear bearing was't mine

Printer:

HicTop Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed in PLA only, with 0.2mm layer height at the beggining and then 0.3.
Designed in Solidworks. Most of parts have more than one version because of updates, better use the latest ones, but i've included all versions of both .stl and source files.

title: Tevo Tarantula Dual Inverted Z Motor Mounts with Oldham Couplers and screw adjustable limit swich

description.text:
This is dual inverted Z setup for Tevo Tarantula printer. I designed this because other similar setups did not worked for me (no clearance for Z limit switch and other problems). This setup it well tested and working with stock Tevo Tarantula printer and also with Mackers.it carbon fiber upgrade. It also includes Oldham couplers (check it here: https://youtu.be/5uvDgNP4m2o) to get rid of any Z wobble caused by thread rods not being straight and new adjustable mechanism for setting Z limit switch distance using screw.

Did you find this thing useful? I spent huge amount of time designing and finetuning this - it would be nice if you consider supporting me via my patreon page so I can create more useful things in future! https://www.patreon.com/tomfrajer

Thank you!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30% Full Honeycomb

Notes:

You will need to use supports for Right motor mount and Limit switch bracket. Default setting for supports in Simplify3D will do well. Also do not forget to rotate all parts so they will lay flat side on bed and you will have minimum overhangs that need support.

1, Print Left_motor_bracket.stl and Right_Motor_Bracket.stl
2, If you want to use screw adjustable limit switch feature, print Limit_Switch_Mount.stl and Limit_Switch_Screw_Holder.stl
3, If you want to use oldham coupler, print 2x Oldham_Coupler_Bottom.stl, 2x Oldham_Coupler_Middle.stl and 2x Oldham_Coupler_Top.stl. If you do not need/want couplers, print 2x Leadscrew_Nut_Bracket.stl instead

Glue on limit switch block

Depending on what fit you will have - in case of limit switch mounting block is not tight fit, simply glue it in place!

Invert Z axis

You need to invert Z axis movement direction in firmware. Open firmware source in Arduino, connect printer to computer via USB, edit this line in Config.h and upload your changes:

define INVERT_Z_DIR true

comments.author: k014

comments.text: Brass nut goes into bottom piece of coupling and stays there bolted. Top part of coupling is bolted to the X axis gantry. These two parts are losely coupled - that is purporse of oldham coupler. X gantry just lays on the botom pieces (with nuts) that are pushing up and down. As there is unrestricted movement in XY of the oldham coupling, any vibrations, imperfections in construction of printer etc. ar damped with this mechanism and only thing that remains is pure vertical Z axis movement. This helps to reduce any waviness in vertical faces of the print. You should try it, works very well! Im stil using this...

title: QU-BD One Up and Two Up Z-Bearing Alignment Spacer Upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This spacer will upgrade the QU-BD One Up and Two Up printer so that the distance between the threaded Z-screw and the smooth Z-rod are at the correct distance from each other, and better constrain the linear bearings to reduce the sagging of the gantry. Installing this upgrade will reduce or eliminate the Z-banding caused by the binding of the vertical motion of the gantry due to binding of the Z-screw and the nut. By stiffening the alignment of the linear bearings to the gantry, this upgrade also improves the alignment of the gantry to the Z-rods. This reduces the vertical skew on printed parts. Designed for the One Up, as I don't have a Two Up to test - I have now uploaded a Two Up version which is experimental and unverified, but I believe it should work. If someone can give it a try, that'll be great! Be sure to read the instructions! Please like and/or collect this thing if you plan to add this to your printer, and please post your make! Thanks!

Interesting in buying a set? Read on... A number of people have commented on not being able to print their own spacer, as they don't have a working 3D printer. Unlike the sometimes missing base plate for the extruder, you can actually assemble your printer without this part and start using it. It's what I did -- the Z screw is a little bit bent because of this, but not by very much. HOWEVER, if you still would rather have that part from the start, I'll be happy to print them for you - please visit http://toybuilderlabs.com/qu-bd-one-up-z-bearing-alignment-spacer-special/ for details.

Print two pieces for the One Up, or three pieces for the Two Up. Clean the prints and smooth out any high spots. Carefully check for fit, especially if there's a lot of Z-wobble on an non-upgraded printer. Mount the spacer onto the main gantry piece (see picture for reference), and then install bearings. Careful when tightening the zip tie! I cracked my MDF in one location from being too aggressive. I now suggest using two zip-ties per installation. Instead of looping the strap back into the latch of the same zip-tie, go through the latch of the second zip, making sure to get sufficient tension. I've found using a plier to pull the strap, and using a screw driver to press down the latch works well. If you had Z-wobbles before, compare the prints after installing the spacer -- on my setup, it has cut down the Z wobble by quite a lot. Please "Like", "Collect", or "I made this" if you like and used the design! Thanks! Please check out more QU-BD One Up related updates at http://toybuilderlabs.com/blog

comments.text: This made all the difference in the world for my OneUp. I had a skew problem due to the sag in the gantry, but this helped a lot!

description.text:
By request of a thingiverse.com user this is a panel (for installing in boxes or walls ) version of the top of the enclosure ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1934646 ) for the new - SMD based hardware version of the DiY geiger counter ( http://www.ebay.com/itm/162282227238?ssPageName=STRK:MESELX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1555.l2649 and https://github.com/impexeris/DiY-Arduino-Geiger-Counter-SMD/tree/master/Enclosure%20.files%20for%203D%20printing ) by my colleague - eBay vendor impexeris ( http://www.ebay.com/usr/impexeris) .

It is for use with SBM-20 or CTC-5 geiger tubes.

push-buttons are on the inside (apparently iR remote is used instead of them)
"click/tone" switch also on the inside (probably not used)
The power switch can be installed by removing thin mask over the opening.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Suggested print settings for PLA:

0.4 mm print-head
0.25 mm resolution
20% in-fill ratio
2 shells
50mm/s default printing speed (may depend on your PLA)
50℃ heated bed
215℃ print-head temperature (may depend on your PLA)
100% fan speed
25% Support in-fill ratio
printing volume enclosure used

no raft and no brim if you have a good adhesion (this way top panel prints smooth and requires no post processing.

! However if you a struggling with adhesion - use all counter means possible as this is the prolonged part with sharp straight corners and especially if you have to print on cold bed without Buildtak surface and no printer volume enclosure you will most certainly have a curl at the corners.
